programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: Billie and Christy use magic in an effort to destroy the reputations of the Charmed Ones.

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: The Charmed Ones are stuck in the Underworld; Leo's ghost appears to Piper and offers demonic approval; a large battle ensues.

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: Piper travels back in time to change the events leading to the deaths of Paige and Phoebe; when the sisters are reunited they get a glimpse of what the future holds for them.

programme.title: Charmed

programme.desc: Prue discovers a devastating betrayal; Piper falls for the ghost of a recently murdered man who needs her help; Phoebe works as a psychic to help others.

programme.title: Charmed

programme.title: Walking Tall
programme.desc: When decorated military officer Chris Vaughn returns to his hometown in the state of Washington to find work, he finds that the lumber mill has closed and the town's big business is now a seedy casino operated by one of his old schoolmates, Jay Hamilton. Aided by his loyal friend Ray Templeton, Vaughn tries to make a stand against the area's crime and corruption, but, finding no help from the police, he must take matters into his own hands.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: A framework for an exploration of Jewish influences on Jesus; being a Jew in the ancient world; Jewish temples; similarities between Judaism and other ancient religions.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: There is little distinction between religion and politics in ancient Judaism; the importance of the law in Jewish religion; the connections between the giving of the law to Moses on Mount Sinai and the Sermon on the Mount.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: A look at the kingdoms of David and Solomon; the transformation of 12 Israelite tribes into a monarchy; how it is crumbling over tensions regarding how to properly worship the God of Israel; probing controversies.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: The end of the First Temple Period; examining the reign of King Josiah; his popular religious reforms reassert the importance of Jerusalem's Temple; the Temple's traumatic destruction; its relationship to Gospel accounts and the Second Temple.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: The Babylonian exile ends; the returning exiles begun to re-establish themselves in Jerusalem under Ezra and Nehemiah; this leads to a dramatic schism between Jews and Samaritans; encounters with Samaritans.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: Insights into the ancient Jewish diaspora communities; close readings of the Book of Tobit and the Book of Esther; insights into the directions from books about holiness and the treatment of other people; a historical literary debate.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: Alexander the Great's visit to Jerusalem and Judea; his influence on the development of ancient Jewish traditions; examining possible narrative parallels between these two iconic figures of Western history.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: The Heliodorus Affair; the power struggle between Jerusalem's elite families during the time of the Ptolemies and Seleucids; how it is a key turning point in the history of Jews in Judea; echoes of this conflict in Gospel accounts of taxation.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: Professor Koester introduces one of the most discussed books of all time; the Book of Revelation, also known as the Apocalypse; the original meaning of apocalypse; the importance of the apocalyptic tradition; the three-part structure of the course.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: The world of the Hebrew prophets, whose writings deeply influence the author of the Apocalypse; the themes of evil and hope in such works as Ezekiel and Isaiah; how these themes are taken up in the Dead Sea Scrolls and the apocalyptic book of Daniel.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: The apocalyptic worldview, with its sense of conflicting powers, is transformed by Christian writers in the New Testament; apocalyptic themes have a primary place in the early church; the religious matrix out of which the book of Revelation arises.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: A close study of the text of the Apocalypse; looking behind the legends to surmise what can be said about its origins and author, identified only as John; examining the peculiar quality of John's Greek, which is not apparent in most translations.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: The first two chapters of Revelation discuss the issues of the Christian communities that first receive the book; the experiences of the men and women addressed by John; the nature of the persecution and other problems; who this book is written for.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: John's distinctive images; his word pictures have captured the imaginations of readers for centuries; plunging into some of John's most vivid scenes; the breaking of the seven seals, which unleashes the four horsemen and other startling visions.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: The middle section of the Apocalypse from two perspectives; the futurist view that Revelation is a book of ominous predictions; the literary view that seeks to understand how John organizes his details into a narrative that is surprisingly hopeful.

programme.title: The Apocalypse: Controversies and Meaning in Western History
programme.desc: Some dramatic scenes in the Apocalypse; dealing with the problem of evil, personified by Satan, the great red dragon; John's account draws on an ancient fascination with stories of good battling evil; he gives a new interpretation to the conflict.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: Alexander the Great's visit to Jerusalem and Judea; his influence on the development of ancient Jewish traditions; examining possible narrative parallels between these two iconic figures of Western history.

programme.title: Jesus and His Jewish Influences
programme.desc: The Heliodorus Affair; the power struggle between Jerusalem's elite families during the time of the Ptolemies and Seleucids; how it is a key turning point in the history of Jews in Judea; echoes of this conflict in Gospel accounts of taxation.

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: Cosmology takes the entire universe as its subject, not just its form, structure and contents, but also the manner of its birth and evolution; looking at the origin of cosmology in creation stories and its relation to the journey ahead.

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: Introducing the hierarchy of structures in the universe; from planets to stars, galaxies, galaxy clusters and larger groupings of galaxies called the cosmic web; light travels at a finite speed, looking far away also means looking far back in time.

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: Discussing cosmic properties; the universe is lumpy at the scale of galaxies and galaxy clusters; at larger scales, it is smooth and similar in all directions; this property of homogeneity and isotropy is called the cosmological principle.

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: The most familiar constituents of the universe are atomic matter and light; neutrinos make up another component; 96 percent of the universe is dark energy and dark matter; the relative amounts of these constituents changes as the universe expands.

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: Taking a trip through the universal timeline from the big bang to a future of ever-accelerating expansion; the eight key stages between them include the condensation of atoms, the birth of the first stars and the formation of galaxies.

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: Astronomers overlap techniques of "distance ladder" to determine distances in the universe; triangulation works for nearby stars; observers use pulsating stars for farther objects, the rotation of galaxies and a class of supernova explosions.

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: Measuring the Doppler shift of galaxies in the early 20th century; observations reveal that they all were moving away from Earth; the more distant ones move faster, proportional to distance; this is the Hubble Law, implying the initial "big bang."

programme.title: Cosmology: The History and Nature of Our Universe
programme.desc: Professor Whittle defines distances in cosmology; the three important distances to consider is the emission distance when the light is set out; the current distance, when the light arrives; the distance the light travels.

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: Illustrating scientific debates over the rise of humans; the ancestry casts Ramapithecus out; witnessing fossil evidence and molecular evidence, working both together and independently; explaining some of anthropology's most complex issues.

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: Discovering and debating over fossil remains of a possible Homo ancestor, Australopithecus afarensis, in 1970; following the story from the perspective of the key personalities involved, scientists Don Johanson and Richard Leakey.

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: Discovering the 4.4-million-year-old remains of Ardipithecus ramidus; debating whether it is a true hominin or not; suggesting a mix between an effective climber and walking bipedally; examining the fossil and genetic evidence of this "ground ape."

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: A human's brain separates them more from apes than any other anatomical feature; investigating the gradual increase in hominid brain size; fossil skulls revealing facts about blood circulation; shedding light on brain size and skull structure.

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: Exploring the link between diet and morphology in Australopithecus robustus and Africanus; the teeth and jaws of these two species offer fierce debates about dietary hypotheses; adaptive differences between robust and gracile hominids.

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: Wondering whether Africa or Asia is closer to human origins; drawing on the ideas and theories of prominent scientists like Charles Darwin, Ernst Haeckel and Louis Leakey; learning how scientists trace the origin and evolution of the genus Homo.

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: Tools mark a major step in evolution, but even chimpanzees can make and use tools; Professor Martin offers a detailed picture of early stone toolmakers; illustrating some of the primitive tools found in parts of Africa.

programme.title: The Rise of Humans: Great Scientific Debates
programme.desc: Fossil records reveal that Homo habilis serves as a transitional marker between Australopithecines and the rest of the genus Homo; Homo habilis has the anatomy to be ancestors of the genus Homo yet not exist at the right time in evolutionary history.

programme.title: World War II: Up Close and Personal
programme.desc: The horrors of Nazi Germany are one hallmark of World War II; pondering how ordinary German citizens find themselves participating in such heinous events; going inside the propaganda machine of Hitler's Germany; seeing how it targets the youth.

programme.title: World War II: Up Close and Personal
programme.desc: The origins of World War II lie in Asia in 1931; tracing the invasion of 1937 and the Rape of Nanjing; witnessing the events through the eyes of a Chinese soldier and a Japanese journalist, young men who bear witness to the flesh and blood of battle.

programme.title: World War II: Up Close and Personal
programme.desc: In addition to the story of people, World War II is the story of technology; perhaps nowhere is this more apparent than the tanks Germany uses to barrel across Poland and France in "lightning warfare"; how new technology defeats the old ways of war.

programme.title: World War II: Up Close and Personal
programme.desc: Wartime Warsaw offers a gateway to the darkest events of the war; bearing witness as the city's Jews are rounded up and put in the ghetto, where the specter of disease and starvation always looms; stories from several of the ghetto's inhabitants.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: If war is a gamble, then a strategy is key to success; a survey of why strategy is important; looking at World War II's "Operation Torch" as a case study for how the military should be used as an instrument of policy.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: A systematic look at what makes Thucydides perhaps history's first great strategist; his analysis of the Peloponnesian War; the political origins of the war; the Spartan and Athenian leadership; the social and moral implications of war.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Joining a debate over the efficacy of the Sicilian Expedition; turning to the Melian Dialogue; the debate between realists and neoconservatives over the conduct of war; considering how this debate still plays out in contemporary America.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Sun Tzu's writing is popular in the modern world; the historical context for "Master Sun's Military Methods"; an overview of Sun Tzu's strategy for war, which is to be efficient, avoid protracted wars and value the commander's intellect and skill.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Charting Sun Tzu's historical importance throughout Chinese history, in feudal and modern Japan, and in the modern West; learning Sun Tzu's strategy of deception in action by exploring Operation Fortitude in the Allied invasion of Normandy.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Learning about Machiavelli, the Italian Renaissance man who writes his own "The Art of War" in which he advocates a citizen-army; going through Machiavelli's book of tactics, which is his recommendation for Florentine military rulers.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Discovering fortuna, which is Machiavelli's philosophy of circumstances, and virtu, which is his recipe for military action; the strategies Machiavelli thinks a republican military should adopt; the qualities to look for in a good commander.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Experiencing the battles of Jena and Auerstedt during the Napoleonic Wars; these two decisive victories demonstrate the radical transformation of warfare; they give rise to Antoine-Henri Jomini and Carl von Clausewitz, two important masters of war.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: In the course's inaugural episode, begin to explore the transformation of violent conflicts between major world powers by delving into a particularly recent example: America's 20-year war in Afghanistan.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: The factors that explain why wars between great powers look different nowadays, and explore what future conflicts could look like between the United States and two of its major adversaries.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: How five contemporary technologies-the Kalashnikov assault rifle, improvised explosive devices, guided missiles, drones, and cyber warfare-redefined the rules of battle and leveled the playing field between world powers and insurgent groups.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: The series of events that followed World War II from the allied occupation of Germany to the Greek Civil War; how the Soviet Union contended with insurgencies and the beginnings of conflict between the United States and the USSR.

programme.title: The Age of Benjamin Franklin
programme.desc: In Franklin's unfinished autobiography, he creates a persona for himself as a role model others may follow; there is more to Franklin than he shows on the page; surveying the book offers some foundational insights into his life and his worldview.

programme.title: The Age of Benjamin Franklin
programme.desc: The Franklins are a typical 18th-century family, extended across space; filled with comedy and tragedy, wealth and poverty; meeting his parents and siblings; learning the story of his wife and first-born son; accompanying Franklin on his travels.

programme.title: The Age of Benjamin Franklin
programme.desc: One may associate Franklin with Philadelphia, but his roots lie in Boston; many of the virtues Franklin cultivates throughout his life grow from the values of the Boston Puritans; witnessing the events that Franklin experiences in his youth.

programme.title: The Age of Benjamin Franklin
programme.desc: Shifting attention to the City of Brotherly Love; 18th-century Philadelphia is one of the leading cities in British America; it is one of the leading cities in the British Empire; what makes this city so important; how the city shapes Franklin.

programme.title: The Agency: A History of the CIA
programme.desc: Why the United States created a secret foreign intelligence service; examining three periods of U.S. government intelligence before the birth of the CIA; the American Revolution to the late 1930s; World War II; the postwar years from 1945 to 1947.

programme.title: The Agency: A History of the CIA
programme.desc: How the CIA transformed from an intelligence agency to housing the United States' premier covert-action unit in the space of just two years; the role of George F. Kennan, who declared political warfare against the Soviet Union.

programme.title: The Agency: A History of the CIA
programme.desc: The CIA's attention to Asia; how the CIA failed to rein in its emphasis on covert operations and restore its focus on intelligence; a lack of public scrutiny of the CIA's actions; the arrival of future CIA director Allen Dulles.

programme.title: The Agency: A History of the CIA
programme.desc: The 1953 Iran Coup and how it created a culture of covert action that would shape the CIA's future; studying the shifting political attitudes toward Iranian nationalism; analyzing the Iran operation; pondering who was most responsible.

programme.title: The American West: History, Myth, and Legacy
programme.desc: Fur traders and mountain men play an integral part in exploring and mapping the American West; why fur is a precious commodity; how John Jacob Astor dominates the American fur trade; how famous mountaineers like Jedediah Smith become legends.

programme.title: The American West: History, Myth, and Legacy
programme.desc: One of the most dismal episodes in the story of the American West; the forced migration of the "Five Civilized Tribes" under the Indian Removal Act of 1830; it is this ordeal that the Cherokee come to call the "Trail of Tears".

programme.title: The American West: History, Myth, and Legacy
programme.desc: From 1830 to 1890, the lives of the Plains Indians change irrevocably; the early history of the Plains Indians; the importance of buffalo and horses to life on the Great Plains; two visitors' perspectives on America's treatment of the Plains Indians.

programme.title: The American West: History, Myth, and Legacy
programme.desc: The story behind the last stand at the Alamo; the tale of the Texas republic; what leads to tensions between the Mexican government and the United States; why the idea of rebellion is crucial to the myth of Texas; how the territory joins the U.S.

programme.title: The Great Tours: Civil War Battlefields
programme.desc: Exploring the significance of battlefields and the methods employed by soldiers in combat.

programme.title: The Great Tours: Civil War Battlefields
programme.desc: Marching from Washington, Irvin McDowell's Union forces encounter P. G. T. Beauregard's Confederate troops at Virginia's Bull Run.

programme.title: The American Civil War
programme.desc: Stonewall Jackson fights in the Shenandoah Valley; Joseph E. Johnston attacks McClellan at Seven Pines or Fair Oaks; in the Seven Days' Battles, Robert E. Lee seizes the initiative and presses the Federals south to the James; Lee saves Richmond.

programme.title: The Great Tours: Civil War Battlefields
programme.desc: In the Second Battle of Bull Run, lieutenants James Longstreet and Thomas Stonewall Jackson play a crucial role in securing victory for Robert E. Lee.

programme.title: The Age of Benjamin Franklin
programme.desc: In Franklin's unfinished autobiography, he creates a persona for himself as a role model others may follow; there is more to Franklin than he shows on the page; surveying the book offers some foundational insights into his life and his worldview.

programme.desc: Wartime Warsaw offers a gateway to the darkest events of the war; bearing witness as the city's Jews are rounded up and put in the ghetto, where the specter of disease and starvation always looms; stories from several of the ghetto's inhabitants.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: If war is a gamble, then a strategy is key to success; a survey of why strategy is important; looking at World War II's "Operation Torch" as a case study for how the military should be used as an instrument of policy.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: A systematic look at what makes Thucydides perhaps history's first great strategist; his analysis of the Peloponnesian War; the political origins of the war; the Spartan and Athenian leadership; the social and moral implications of war.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Joining a debate over the efficacy of the Sicilian Expedition; turning to the Melian Dialogue; the debate between realists and neoconservatives over the conduct of war; considering how this debate still plays out in contemporary America.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Sun Tzu's writing is popular in the modern world; the historical context for "Master Sun's Military Methods"; an overview of Sun Tzu's strategy for war, which is to be efficient, avoid protracted wars and value the commander's intellect and skill.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Charting Sun Tzu's historical importance throughout Chinese history, in feudal and modern Japan, and in the modern West; learning Sun Tzu's strategy of deception in action by exploring Operation Fortitude in the Allied invasion of Normandy.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Learning about Machiavelli, the Italian Renaissance man who writes his own "The Art of War" in which he advocates a citizen-army; going through Machiavelli's book of tactics, which is his recommendation for Florentine military rulers.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Discovering fortuna, which is Machiavelli's philosophy of circumstances, and virtu, which is his recipe for military action; the strategies Machiavelli thinks a republican military should adopt; the qualities to look for in a good commander.

programme.title: Masters of War: History's Greatest Strategic Thinkers
programme.desc: Experiencing the battles of Jena and Auerstedt during the Napoleonic Wars; these two decisive victories demonstrate the radical transformation of warfare; they give rise to Antoine-Henri Jomini and Carl von Clausewitz, two important masters of war.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: In the course's inaugural episode, begin to explore the transformation of violent conflicts between major world powers by delving into a particularly recent example: America's 20-year war in Afghanistan.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: The factors that explain why wars between great powers look different nowadays, and explore what future conflicts could look like between the United States and two of its major adversaries.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: How five contemporary technologies-the Kalashnikov assault rifle, improvised explosive devices, guided missiles, drones, and cyber warfare-redefined the rules of battle and leveled the playing field between world powers and insurgent groups.

programme.title: War in the Modern World
programme.desc: The series of events that followed World War II from the allied occupation of Germany to the Greek Civil War; how the Soviet Union contended with insurgencies and the beginnings of conflict between the United States and the USSR.

programme.title: World War II: Up Close and Personal
programme.desc: The horrors of Nazi Germany are one hallmark of World War II; pondering how ordinary German citizens find themselves participating in such heinous events; going inside the propaganda machine of Hitler's Germany; seeing how it targets the youth.

programme.title: World War II: Up Close and Personal
programme.desc: The origins of World War II lie in Asia in 1931; tracing the invasion of 1937 and the Rape of Nanjing; witnessing the events through the eyes of a Chinese soldier and a Japanese journalist, young men who bear witness to the flesh and blood of battle.

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World

programme.title: Great Board Games of the Ancient World

programme.title: Ocean's Thirteen
programme.desc: Danny Ocean and his gang hatch an ambitious plot for revenge after ruthless casino owner Willy Bank double-crosses Reuben Tishkoff, Danny's friend and mentor. First, Ocean's gang plan to hit Bank in the paycheck by reversing the precept that the house always wins. Next, they will deal a crushing blow to Bank's ego by ruining his reputation as the only hotelier to earn the Royal Review's Five Diamond Award for each of his properties.

programme.title: Ocean's Twelve
programme.desc: After successfully robbing five casinos in one night, Danny Ocean and his crew of thieves have big problems. Despite pulling off one of the biggest heists in Las Vegas history, the members of the gang have already spent much of the money they stole. Casino owner Terry Benedict demands that Ocean return the money, plus millions more in interest. Unable to come up the cash, the crew is forced to come together to pull off another series of heists, this time in Europe.
